1151598285867667457.text:
I thank the Virginia delegation for supporting this bipartisan legislation to honor Keith’s legacy and impact on our Virginia Beach community. 

I urge support of this bill and yield back my time. (11/11)

1151598284835905538.text: I was proud to introduce this bill to name a local post office after Keith. When we walk by that post office and see Keith’s name, we’ll think of his sacrifice and the lives he saved. (10/11)

1151598283837644800.text:
He was a true servant leader who made the ultimate sacrifice. 

This is our chance to tell Keith’s story, to showcase his heroism to our community, our Commonwealth, and our nation.  (9/11)

1151598283158167552.text: One of Keith’s colleagues summed it up: “If it wasn’t for him, there would have been several more people that had perished.” In our community’s darkest hour, Keith prioritized the safety of his colleagues over his own. (8/11)

1151598282302513154.text: During the shooting, Keith led several of his coworkers to safety. Keith then refused to take refuge, stating: “I’ve got to see if anybody else needs help.” Keith stood watch and checked on his colleagues, voluntarily exposing himself to a deadly line of fire. (7/11)

1151598281409126400.text: Those who knew him say Keith embodied leadership. Keith’s friends and family agree that he made his impact by putting the needs of others before his own. Keith’s last day on Earth was no different. (6/11)

1151598280603820033.text:
One coworker called Keith a “teddy bear” who always knew what to say to make an upset colleague smile.

Those who knew him say Keith embodied leadership. Keith’s friends and family agree that he made his impact by putting the needs of others before his own. (5/11)

1151598279844597767.text: For 12 years, Keith served the City of Virginia Beach as a public utilities employee. His coworkers described him as someone who was always nice to others and treated colleagues to lunch. (4/11)

1151598279077105665.text: He had hoped to follow his calling and in his father’s footsteps and become more active in ministry. (3/11)

1151598278171123713.text:
In his final moments, Keith showed extraordinary bravery.

Keith was an active and irreplaceable member of our community. He regularly attended his father’s church, New Hope Baptist, where he sang in the choir with his renowned “golden voice.” (2/11)

1151598277420290049.text:
I rise today to honor the life and heroic actions of Ryan “Keith” Cox.

On May 31st, the year’s largest mass shooting in America struck our Virginia Beach community. Keith was among the 12 wonderful people who lost their lives in the tragedy. (1/11)

1141421050137382912.text: #Juneteenth marks 154 years since the end of slavery in America. On June 19, 1865, the Emancipation Proclamation finally reached Texas. Today, we reflect on the progress we have made, while recommitting ourselves to combating racism and inequalities in opportunity.

1136988352878694400.text:
We are #VBStrong. I am so proud to call Hampton Roads home. This is a place packed with heroes. 

My heart remains with the families, the injured, the first responders, and our entire community. 

#LoveForVB #VBRemembers (3/3)

1136988351574286336.text: Our law enforcement and city officials showed tremendous strength, our community memorials showed love to the 12 wonderful people we lost far too soon, and our vigil showed the immense power of thousands coming together as one. (2/3)

1136676572914733056.text: I thank Virginia’s Congressional Delegation for showing strong support for our community. Swift passage of this resolution will make clear that the Commonwealth and nation grieve with Virginia Beach. (2/2) https://t.co/HKTqjVThQ0

1136381692535611393.text: All 11 Virginia U.S. House Members stand united in bipartisan support for 12 wonderful people we lost far too soon, their families and loved ones, and all of Virginia Beach. (1/2) https://t.co/8CWHj1r98j

1136038800189263872.text:
To him, it was never an option to not act. If there is a lesson that we take out of this tragedy, all we have to do is look at him.  

We must run into the building together. We must act.

1136038799321051136.text:
This is a moment where doing nothing is no longer an option. 

To prove that point, all we have to do is look at the first responder who ran into the building and took a bullet to protect his fellow citizens.

1136038798616408067.text:
Bert Snelling’s neighbor told a Virginian-Pilot reporter: “It’s the world we live in now, and it’s a shame.” A friend of Missy Langer’s told The Washington Post: “This kind of stuff has got to stop.” Another friend said: “She didn’t deserve to die like that.”

None of them did.

1136038797714644992.text: Those who knew the victims are making statements that we need to hear.

1136038796938633216.text: I saw strength among our city leaders and police chief as they addressed our grieving community — determined to remember the 12 we lost far too soon.

1136038796213047301.text: I saw love and hope at heartfelt vigils across our community where people of all faiths joined in prayer to remember those who left us all too soon.

1136038795374202880.text: I saw unbelievable bravery at Sentara Hospital, where Sunday I had the honor of visiting a survivor of the shooting. She clasped my hand as I stood at her bedside, and her strength and resolve were palpable, as she had only narrowly come away alive.

1136038794598277120.text: That includes including the officer, among the first responders, who in the performance of his duties took a bullet to protect our community, and was by the grace of God saved by his protective vest.

1136038793818058752.text: As the hours and days go by, we hear tens if not hundreds of stories of the heroism of individuals who helped save lives during this tragic event.

1136038793155358721.text: Over the weekend, I saw heroic first responders — police, fire, and EMS personnel — who ran into the line of fire to save others before comforting our community in the immediate aftermath of this tragedy.

1136038792463355904.text: The losses here will never be replaced. But so many heroes emerged to prevent further horror.

1136038790378770436.text: Robert “Bobby” Williams, a special projects coordinator who lived in Chesapeake, worked for Virginia Beach for 41 years. He helped build the sea wall in our city and planned on retiring this year to spend more time with his family. https://t.co/Fj0UIi7LkG

1136038788860469249.text: Herbert “Bert” Snelling, a contractor who lived in Virginia Beach and was visiting the Municipal Center for a permit, led his church’s security team. In his work, he did everything from small handyman repair to building homes. https://t.co/v8MvkRkJIK

1136038787421806592.text: Christopher Kelly Rapp, an engineer who lived in Powhatan, played the bagpipes and loved Scottish music. Compared by some to Mr. Rogers, he was known as encouraging and enthusiastic. https://t.co/RCkTVJwtK8

1136038785978945537.text: Katherine A. Nixon, an engineer who lived in Virginia Beach, was a devoted wife and mother to three daughters, one of whom is just 15 months old. According to her neighbor, her final call was to her husband, just moments after she was shot. https://t.co/Kd6an85Rc1

1136038784620015618.text: Richard H. Nettleton, an engineer who lived in Norfolk, helped design, install, and maintain Virginia Beach’s water and sewer systems. An Army veteran, he enjoyed mentoring young engineers. https://t.co/0yQulYGD8r

1136038782921318402.text: Michelle “Missy” Langer, an administrative assistant who lived in Virginia Beach, loved the Pittsburgh Steelers, Paul McCartney, and the ocean. A friend said: “I will miss her smile and her hugs. That’s the hardest thing.” https://t.co/uBl6QopXbz

1136038780580876289.text: Joshua O. Hardy, an engineering technician who lived in Virginia Beach, was a loving uncle. A healthy eater and runner, he smiled on the job and found time to write a beloved children’s book that spoke to youth about “strangers in their midst.” https://t.co/ZjKFlyxhMc

1136038779343556608.text: Alexander Mikhail Gusev, a right-of-way agent who lived in Virginia Beach, moved from Belarus to seek a better life in America. He was a generous and thoughtful person who was said to grab his lawnmower and cut his neighbor’s lawn without even being asked. https://t.co/hFYiA0y4mX

1136038777527267328.text: Mary Louise Gayle was a right-of-way agent who lived in Virginia Beach. A proud grandmother, she had just turned 65, and her children planned to take their mom to Portland later this month to celebrate her birthday. https://t.co/gUaNhURSjJ

1136038775241547777.text: Tara Welch Gallagher, an engineer who lived in Virginia Beach, educated the public about clean water and served her city for six years. Tara’s survivors include her husband and 22-month-old son. Her husband told a reporter: “She was everything to me.” https://t.co/nxSP0lZBtn

1136038774587174913.text: During the shooting, Keith guided colleagues to safety, but did not join them so he could look out for others.

1136038773177880578.text: Ryan Keith Cox, an account clerk who lived in Virginia Beach, had a “golden voice” & sang in his church choir. He had recently accepted his own calling to the ministry, to follow in the footsteps of his father, Pastor E. Ray Cox, a friend & the pastor of New Hope Baptist Church. https://t.co/ZQQkDPBKZF

1136038771877711872.text: Laquita C. Brown, a right-of-way agent who lived in Chesapeake, was an avid traveler who chronicled trips to New York City, Europe, and West Africa. A friend of hers called her “Ms. Worldwide.” Her 40th birthday was coming up in November. https://t.co/L9GcHZtfjY

1136038771097575424.text: Eleven of them were devoted public servants with more than 150 years of combined experience, and one was a dedicated contractor. I am honored to remember them today.

1136036957740576768.text: Today I grieve for Virginia Beach, a great city in our district where America's most devastating mass shooting of the year happened last Friday. That morning, 12 innocent people left their homes for work. But they didn’t return home to their families, and they never will. https://t.co/4T7j0eIXn8

1135946594120024064.text: This website is a great way to get information about how you can help in Virginia Beach. You can read more about the 12 we lost far too soon, find information on upcoming vigils, seek volunteer opportunities, and more. https://t.co/BYNTy8oYQs

1135684653531246593.text: My team and I proudly wore blue today to honor the 12 wonderful people we lost last Friday. We are working in Washington, but our hearts are in Virginia Beach. #VBStrong #LoveForVB #TogetherVB #WearBlue https://t.co/iPj9rkaESj

1135649343598419969.text: A quick update that the Family Assistance Center will be open through Friday, June 7, from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. More details here, under the "Latest Updates" tab: https://t.co/BYNTy8oYQs https://t.co/ZtYxd03IyG

1135586332506501120.text:
As I travel to Washington for votes in Congress, the honored 12, their families, and our community are foremost in my heart. (3/3)

#LoveForVB #VBStrong #TogetherVB

1135585990456893444.text: Seeing three of the 12 grieving families illustrated the incalculable cost of these random acts of workplace violence. Virginia Beach is strong. We will continue to come together to remember those we lost far too soon. (2/3)

1135585987952893953.text: I was deeply moved while attending the City of Virginia Beach employee convocation this morning. City Manager Dave Hansen’s leadership during this difficult time is an inspiration. (1/3)

1135582854891655170.text:
Representatives are on site for survivors and families to provide counseling, advice, financial planning, and more. I thank all the counselors, regional organizations, and staff who are on hand to help to support our community. (2/2)

#LoveforVB #VBStrong #TogetherVB

1135582854228905984.text: A note for Virginia Beach city employees and families. The Family Assistance Center (FAC) has relocated to Princess Anne Recreation Center, located at 1400 Nimmo Parkway. The FAC is open until 8 p.m. today. (1/2)

1135309089976856582.text:
I saw our community’s determination to keep the honored 12 forever in our memories. 

We are #VBStrong. (7/7)

1135309088605253632.text: I saw strength among our city leaders and law enforcement officials as they addressed our similarly grieving local press and described a heartbreaking timeline of events that struck our city. (6/7)

1135309087250497536.text: I saw love and hope at heartfelt vigils yesterday at Bridge Church and today at Piney Grove Baptist Church. (5/7)

1135309086105489409.text: I saw unbelievable bravery at Sentara Hospital, where I had the honor of visiting with a survivor of Friday’s shooting. (4/7)

1135309084842954752.text: I saw heroic first responders — police, fire, and EMS personnel — who risked their lives to save others before comforting our community in the immediate aftermath of this tragedy. (3/7)

1135309083735658497.text: I saw the faces and learned more about the lives of the 12 incredible people we lost far too soon. (2/7)

1135309080501903362.text: The last 36 hours have reaffirmed the power and unity of Virginia Beach and the Hampton Roads region I am so proud to represent. (1/7)

1134878015819849728.text: #VBStrong Here are ways to help and support those affected by yesterday’s shooting in Virginia Beach: https://t.co/VaDFdkaEfj

1134845551453843456.text: [Note from staff: This weekend Congresswoman Luria’s team in Virginia Beach (757-364-7650) and Washington (202-225-4215) are available to assist and guide constituents to mental health resources, support opportunities, and other available services.] (6/6)

1134845550078103557.text: My focus is on the 12 public servants whose lives were ended too soon, those who were injured, and all their loved ones. My staff and I stand ready to assist. Our community will emerge stronger. (5/6)

1134845548798910464.text: Four others are seriously injured, and we hope for swift recoveries. Our community thanks our incredibly heroic law enforcement officials who responded within minutes to prevent further horror, including a Virginia Beach police officer whose bulletproof vest saved his life. (4/6)

1134845547452542977.text: We remember them and honor their service. Our hearts are with their families and all who knew them, worked beside them, and loved them. (3/6)

1134845543258238982.text: Today we learned the names and record of civil service of the 12 people who were senselessly murdered in yesterday’s devastating act of violence in Virginia Beach. (1/6)

1134623131572850688.text: Now is the time for healing, coming together, and determining ways to prevent this kind of tragedy from happening again. (3/3)

1134623129530241025.text: I wish a speedy recovery to all who are injured, and I thank the first responders, medical personnel, and law enforcement for their invaluable bravery and service. (2/3)

1134623126560616450.text: This is a day that will change Virginia Beach forever. I grieve for those who lost their lives, their families, and everyone who loved them. (1/3)

1134569683854774273.text: My heart is with all those injured & affected by today’s shooting at the Virginia Beach Municipal Center. I’m so thankful for first responders & law enforcement for risking their lives to bring a suspect into custody. This is more proof Congress must act to prevent gun violence.

1134490920878059521.text: Great meeting this morning to discuss legislative progress with the Chesapeake Bay Advisory Board. In Congress, I’m proud to lead on bipartisan legislation to protect and preserve our beautiful Bay! https://t.co/mc6IpVhFuF

1133845182946959361.text: It was especially great to meet students from across the Shore, including the graduating class from Tangier Combined School who made the trip over the island this morning. (3/3) https://t.co/7jWRmLG2Ur
